channel.title: How did you learn Java?
channel.description:
All the people that learn how to code bots ect, I would like to know how you learn how to code so well.
I'm very interested in learning Java, but I can never remember it as such. I use eBooks, but none of them work for me.
Tips/Advice?

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Thanks for the response Sean. I’ll see how I do with that book, and I’ll also buy some more. I’ll have a look at the ones you recommend.

I’ll also take your advice of looking at example code, although, this is better done when I at least have basic knowledge of the language.

The book I’m getting should be coming in 2 days, so within the next 3 weeks, I’ll give you all an update xD

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

sams is not a good publisher, all of their books I have read have disappointed me greatly. The x days series is particualry bad.

If you want to start a fresh with a “for newbies book” theres only one I would ever recommend. http://www.prenhall.com/deitel/ java - how to program. They have been in the game for a long time and introduce uml and design, with exercises for you to do if you wish. It is commonly used in university courses (as is their c++ book) around the world, I know several people that have been taught using their books. And no it isnt too hard for the younger members of the community to understand either, I read the book when I was 15.

But, as we all know, o’reilly is great, but dont expect it to hold your hand along the way (well the only ‘introductory’ java books ive ever glanced at of theirs read more like referance for experianced programmers, rather than introductory to programming and thus explaining concepts you wouldnt otherwise know.)

And a book you really should read? (or atleast one of the many books you really should read) http://java.sun.com/docs/books/effective/ – good book.

List of other (may be updated, the only ones I can bother to think of atm):
hardcore java (very similar to effective java)
Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software - the legendary gof book.

From there it really depends on your interests, I love books myself, ebooks or otherwise. I would disagree with mopman whole heartedly about “dont look at example code”, when you are at the learning stage example code can greatly increase your understanding of something, especially when you play with the code. Is this copy paste coding? No, this is learning. If anything I suspect he says this as he has seen noobs copy paste and claim its their own code, which is a far leap from what im proposing here.

To your original question, how I learnt java. that deitel and deitel book, and many more books after that. Setting myself small projects and large, talking to other developers and generally having a passion for programming in many ways.

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:26, topic:44521”][quote author=ilyaostr9 link=topic=61763.msg744989#msg744989 date=1168147551]

Try explaining a constructor to one of the MoparScape retards. You will find out something halfway through - if you don’t know how they work, prepare to fail horribly.

Try explaining what Java is… ;p
[/quote]

An object oriented programming language much like C, in having a main method and syntactically. You can “throw” Objects that are “instances” of “java/lang/Throwable” during the evaluation of a method in that object. To actually start the invokation chain, you have to declare a method of type void that takes an array of Strings (Text strings of characters) as the argument. That String array represents all the arguments provided from the command line. When such a method throws a Throwable, if some other part of the method decides to catch the Throwable, then the result is another piece of the code is run through, with the extra provision of having the Throwable that got thrown

//etc, I’m lazy.

You’re turn. Constructor. Now.[/quote]

That wasn’t really a description of Java so much as an explanation of strings and error handling.

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

You’re turn. Constructor. Now.

ill have a go, bearing in mind i learnt what they are 2 days ago

a constructor is a method which is called when an object is created, bear in mind the variable doesnt contain the object, it only contains a path to the object, by default a constuctor has no parameters, you can create custom constuctor in a similar way to a method, except you do not specify a return type (not even void), the way the compiler requognises a constuctor is the absence of a return type, here is an example.

public class student{ //i will use this class to make an object of students

private String name;
private int[] mark;

public student(String theName,int[] marks) {
   name = TheName;
   mark = marks;
}

}

when i want to use this class, i would do something like this

student student1 = new student("Yakman",{0,1,2,2,2,0,1,2});

that initiates the object during its its contruction, declaring the variables during the contruction is much less bug-prone than

student student1 = new student();
student1.name="Yakman";

back on topic
i learnt java by reading a eBook, i also download quite a lot of stuff to do with the stuff im reading about, like now its GUI, so iv got most GUI stuff thats on this forum
Open Source FTW!

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cobra Fat Cobra
item.description:
@Fat_Cobra wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:19, topic:44521”]I decided to order this book. Should come by Tuesday

The reviews say that it’s the first book called “learn so and so in X days” that really was worth the buy, and it was great for learning from scratch:

amazon.co.uk

Sams Teach Yourself Java 2 in 21 Days

Rogers Cadenhead, Laura Lemay

3.1 out of 5 stars,


why are you after java 2? shouldnt you learn just java first?
and yeah btw i borrowed ’ sams teach yourself java in 24 hours’ pretty good book but still havent finished it.

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I basically learned all the languages I know by playing around with them and learning by example. Granted it takes far more time than learning from someone else or from a book, and it definitely leads to confusing situations down the road (although I suppose they will be met regardless) , but I honestly can’t pick up a beginning programming book like that and read it.

Anyway, I do think learning from a book would be your best bet, and from what I saw of the book mopar posted, it should be a pretty good beginning guide.

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Way back when Jagex hadn’t completely fucked up the RS client (this was ~version 350) I just picked up a deob and started winging it. I like to think I turned out pretty good, considering how much I played it by ear. I don’t recommend this nowadays, because you’re bound to get confused. Go to your local bookstore and buy a textbook for ~$50 USD (I don’t know what that is in pounds). Of course, if you don’t have the money to waste, don’t destroy your eyesight reading eBooks, go to your local library and check one out there.

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Example code can be used to learn, however learning to program by reading examples can make people end up being copy&paste programmers who use sample code all the time and don’t develop problem solving skills at all. (Look at most VB coders). This is fine in a way and with so much sample stuff available on the net you can build a lot of programs simply from taking bits people have already written. RS Cheating or anything but simple applications though, is going to involve a lot of finding out of your own and if you’ve never needed to do this you’re gonna be stumped.

It’s like when people recommend you write a Tetris clone or something before you try to get into game programming. Read gamedev and count the amount of people who “write” their tetris clone by copying and pasting someone elses code and then wonder why they haven’t magically gained the knowledge required to write their dream MMORPG. I’m not saying using example code is bad, but it’s probably better left until you can already code, imo.

Read full topic

item.title: How did you learn Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
